_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: RL15177-SVC Stripper Tops from V2407 RV

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
WOOD RIVER REFINERY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

REGISTRATION INFORMATION
The May 2020 resubmittal covers the following two changes:
1) A change occurred at the facility that required a revised PHA (40CFR68.190(b)(5)).
The ULD-2 unit was converted from a diesel hydrotreater to a slurry hydrotreater, which resulted in a revised PHA.  There are no new regulated substances above its threshold quantity as a result of the change, but the quantity of regulated substances already present in the unit increased as a result of the change.
2) A change occurred at the facility that required a revised offsite consequence analysis (40CFR68.190(b)(6)).
The DU-4 unit put an out of service vessel back in service, which resulted in a revised offsite consequence analysis impacting a new public receptor.
The above information has been highlighted in the Executive Summary because only one selection from EPA's pick list can be made in the Reason for resubmission in Section 1. Registration.    
 
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
The Wood River Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond and have the ability to control and contain the release.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Wood River Refinery, located in Roxana IL, processes raw crude oil into gasoline and other refining products including jet fuel, diesel fuel, heating oil, heavy fuel oil, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and sulfur. The refinery produces and/or uses several regulated flammables, including hydrogen, methane, ethane, pentane, and LPG products consisting

of butane and propane. The refinery also handles hydrogen sulfide (H2S) but there are no processes with H2S above the threshold quantity.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Wood River Refinery.
Because processes at the refinery that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA
Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program:

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
The Wood River Refinery encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation include updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information, participating as members of audit teams, and participating as members of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and hazard review teams. Employees have access to all information created as part of the refinery accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in a Wood River Refinery PSM Overview refinery procedure.

A culture that drives towards zero accidents and incidents is the focus of Phillips 66's Health, Safety, and Environment Management System Standard. In addition, Wood River Refinery has a number of initiatives that address process failures, process safety, and employee safety issues. These initiatives include: multi-discipline PHA teams, Root Cause Failure Analysis teams, HSE Steering Committee, Joint Health and Safety Committee, and PSM subcommittees. The teams and committees typically consist of members from a broad cross-section of the refinery, including operations, mechanical, technical and plant management. Other means by which employees are solicited for input and feedback on various PSM programs are through safety meetings and audits.

W

ood River Refinery participates in OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) and has earned VPP Star Status. The OSHA VPP Steering committee is comprised of hourly and management personnel.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION (PSI)
The Wood River Refinery keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date PSI. PSI reference documents are readily available as part of the written employee participation. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards, emergency response medical treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). For specific process areas, the refinery has documented operating limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in the unit specific PSI documentation. The refinery ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).
The Wood River Refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA)
The Wood River Refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various p

rocesses are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

The Wood River Refinery primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard and risk evaluation techniques. These analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. The PHA team findings are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution.

For higher severity consequences, Layer of Protection Analyses (LOPAs)augment HAZOPs conducted for each covered process. LOPA is a risk assessment tool that semi-quantitatively evaluates the safety integrity of process operations. LOPA uses a simple numerical calculation to measure the adequacy of protection layers (alarms, relief valves, control loops, etc.) against the potential consequences of process deviations (loss of containment, personnel exposure, etc). The LOPA approximates an order-of-magnitude likelihood for each consequence analyzed.

Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps to ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Wood River Refinery revalidates the hazard ana

lysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained. All documentation is made available to all plant personnel.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
The Wood River Refinery maintains written procedures for each covered process that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference for experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revisiting them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. Unit emergency drills are conducted regularly to evaluate emergency procedures.

In addition, the Wood River Refinery maintains a Process Safety Information document that provides guidance on how to respond to operating limit exceedances for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

TRAINING
To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Wood River Refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in refinery operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a qualified operator to learn process-specific duti

ion plans for refinery incidents that could affect the general public.

CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Wood River Refinery resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.
The following are examples of the types of changes that the Refinery has identified and addressed:
¿	Upgrade process instrumentation
¿	Install emergency isolation valves on vessels storing larger quantities of flammable substances
¿	Install additional gas detection for some processes
¿	Install additional deluge systems 
¿	Install instrumented dual seals and vibration shutdowns/ alarms on higher risk pumps
¿	Upgrade safety instrumented systems for furnaces/heaters
¿	Implement Basic Furnace Safeguarding Strategy for furnaces/ heaters to improve combustion safety through safeguards against fuel-rich combustion and flameout
¿       Improve drainage system at spheres that contain LPG

and miscellaneous portable pumps and trailers.  The response organization operates an on-site emergency dispatching center, and emergency operations center and a live fire training facility.  The refinery has a dedicated firewater system, and has an extensive inventory of evacuation alarms, fire detection systems and specialized fire suppression systems. The refinery contracts with the Code Red alerting system to provide emergency alerting services within the local communities.   

WRR receives mutual aid from area municipal fire departments through a detailed box alarm program. The program provides multiple pre-defined levels of response for all types of significant incidents (fires, hazmat spills/release, technical rescue incidents, and multi-injury) within the refinery from the local fire departments. Alton Memorial Hospital Ambulance Service provides all routine emergency medical transport and ARCH Helicopter provides air medical evacuation services to the refinery. Marine spill response is supplemented by spill response contractors.   

Industrial mutual aid resources in the area are very limited. Most industries in the local Illinois/Missouri area do not actively provide mutual response resources. WRR has been requested to respond to off-site emergencies and usually provides resources if possible. Most off-site mutual aid responses are for specialized equipment (foam pumpers, portable pumps) and only limited manpower staffing is provided for the response. 

The WRR coordinates their emergency response activities with local municipalities and local industries. WRR is an active member of the Mutual Aid Box Alarm System (state of Illinois statewide mutual aid response organization) Division 35, the Region IV Disaster Committee, Alton Memorial Hospital EMS System, and the River Industry Committee for Emergency Response and Preparedness Mutual Aid Group.  WRR personnel routinely attend meetings of these organizations and help coordinate development of mitigat

es and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration, and drawing test) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. Refresher training is conducted at least every three years to assure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

CONTRACTORS
The Wood River Refinery uses contractors to supplement its work force, particularly during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, the Wood River Refinery evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Refinery personnel periodically monitor contractor performance, through audits and regular work site visits, to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSRs)
The Wood River Refinery conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety in

formation. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all-supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
The Wood River Refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels. If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or an MOC team will review the use of the eq

uipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment. 

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. The Wood River Refinery quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

SAFE WORK PRACTICES
The Wood River Refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.
Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel in operating areas, (2) a Lock Out/Tag Out (LOTO) procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) procedures for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control open flame or spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
The Wood River Refinery has a comprehensive system to manage both permanent and temporary changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, environmental hazards, personnel/organizational and other facility changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorp

orate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
The Wood River Refinery promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The level of investigation required is commensurate with the incident's risk ranking. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during initial and revalidation PHAs.

Process safety events (releases, near misses, and challenges to safety systems) are tracked and reported as leading and lagging process safety performance indicators.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Wood River Refinery periodically conducts self-audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance self-audits are conducted at least every 3 years. Both hourly and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The fi

nal resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

Additionally, The Wood River Refinery is the subject to Corporate Safety and Health compliance audits. The audit, which includes OSHA's PSM elements, also includes an extensive overview of the risk management systems.
The audit is conducted by a team of safety and other element specialists from other Phillips 66 facilities to ensure that audits are independent.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The processes at the Wood River Refinery have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operations. The accident prevention program summarized above is applied to all EPA RMP-covered processes at the plant. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential release scenarios that could be caused by (1) human failure, and (2) equipment failure.

In addition to the accident prevention program activities, the Wood River Refinery has safety features on many units to help (1) prevent a release, (2) detect a release, and (3) reduce the effects of a release by mitigating consequences. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

1. PREVENT A RELEASE
* Relief devices directed to a flare gas recovery/flare system
* Engineering Standards that specify suitable construction materials used in vessels, equipment and associated piping
* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)
* Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature, release detection)
* Vessels to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release (e.g., dump tanks)
* Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pumps)
* Tandem seals on high-risk pumps with interstitial alarms
* Critical operating parameters which alarm for operator action
* Check valves for limiting flow in one directio

n

2. DETECT A RELEASE
* Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
* Hydrogen Sulfide detectors (fixed and personnel) with alarms
* Benzene detectors with alarms
* Closed-circuit television cameras

3. MITIGATING THE CONSEQUENSES
* Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases
* Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
* Deluge system for specific equipment
* Trained emergency response personnel
* Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
* Blast-resistant buildings to protect personnel and control systems
* Excess flow valves
* Water spray systems/Deluge system

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
During the past 5 years only one incident occurred at the Wood River Refinery involving a release of a regulated substance that meets RMP reporting requirements. On 2/10/2019, 50,000 lbs of a flammable mixture was released through an open line off an exchanger with a damaged bundle.  The release had no off-site impacts, but the incident did result in one injury and significant property damage.  A formal incident investigation was conducted and improvements included revising the isolation/blinding procedures for exchanger work and requiring a second check of all modified operating startup procedures to prevent similar incidents from occurring.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The Wood River Refinery (WRR) maintains a comprehensive on-site emergency response organization capable of responding to any type of emergency within the refinery. The response organization provides a two tiered approach to emergency response activities. A full time staff provides the backbone of the response team structure. A designated on-shift response team consisting of process operations personnel (process supervisors and quality assurance technicians) and contract security personnel provide additional initial response to emergencies. All of these personnel are trained to the level of advanced exterior firefighting and OSHA hazmat t

echnician. A minimum staffing of trained shift personnel (contract firefighter/paramedic, contract firefighter/EMT, shift supervisors, quality assurance technicians, and contract security guards) provide initial response to emergencies.         

The on-shift response personnel are supplemented by volunteer response team members who staff 7 different teams. The volunteer response teams includes a fire crew, an EMS team, a technical rescue team, a hazmat team, an incident management team, a support crew, and a critical incident stress management team. The volunteer fire fighting crew is also trained to the level of advanced exterior firefighting and OSHA hazmat technician. The EMS team is trained to the level of medical first responder/AED. The technical rescue team is trained to the technician level in rope rescue, confined space, trench rescue, and auto extrication, in addition to the operations level in building collapse and water rescue. The technical rescue team also maintains medical first responder/AED qualification. The hazmat team members are trained to the hazmat specialist level and marine spill response. The Critical Incident Stress Management (CISM) team members are trained to the advanced CISM level. The Incident Command System (ICS) team and support crew attend training specifically geared to their response duties. 

All response team members training meets and/or exceeds the regulatory agency requirements for emergency response training. Extensive standard operating guidelines have been developed to manage response team operations. Training and standard operating guidelines are routinely tested through monthly on-shift emergency drills and quarterly response team drills.

The WRR response team maintains a large fleet of response vehicles that include foam apparatus, a foam aerial, a mini-pumper, an ambulance, technical rescue vehicles, a hazmat vehicle, a hose tender, foam  tenders, command vehicles, quick attack trucks, quick response vehicles
